metadata.title: Buckling loads of nano-beams in stress-driven nonlocal elasticity

sections.text:
ARTICLE HISTORY Received 12 July 2018 Accepted 12 July 2018
KEYWORDS Nonlocal elasticity; nanobeams; size effects; buckling; CNT; NEMS

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Nowadays, nanomaterials are widely and successfully exploited for ground-breaking nanotechnological applications. Design and optimization of nanodevices for NanoElectro-Mechanical Systems (NEMS) can be conveniently carried out by making recourse to size-dependent constitutive laws, see e.g., [1–4]. The differential law, consequent (but not equivalent) to the strain-driven nonlocal integral law proposed by Eringen in his seminal contributions [5] and [6], is the most used model to study nanostructures, see the review papers [7–9] and the references cited therein. The strain-driven integral law provides the stress field as output of the convolution between elastic deformation and a suitable smoothing kernel dependent on a non-local parameter. In a recent paper [10], it has been shown that, adopting the special bi-exponential kernel, the differential law of Eringen is equivalent to the integral one provided that suitable homogeneous constitutive boundary conditions (CBC) are verified. CBC are tacitly fulfilled in nonlocal problems defined in unbounded domains, as originally studied by Eringen, concerning dislocations and wave propagation. On the contrary, in structural problems of engineering interest CBC are in contrast with equilibrium requirements and therefore the consequent elastostatic problems are ill-posed [11]. However, in literature, CBC are often improperly disregarded [12]. This is the basic reason of paradoxes enlightened and debated, see e.g. [13–16]. Inapplicability of straindriven formulations to technical problems of nano-mechanics is acknowledged in a large number of recent papers,
such as [17–25]. All these difficulties can be overcome by adopting the innovative nonlocal constitutive theory, of stress-driven type, proposed in [26] and applied in [27–32] to investigate size-dependent static and dynamic responses of nano-beams. Strain-driven and stress-driven models of nonlocal elasticity are illustrated and carefully compared in a series of recent contributions, see e.g., [33–36].
The motivation of the present paper is in assessing sizedependent buckling loads of compressed Bernoulli-Euler straight nano-beams by making to recourse to the new stress-driven nonlocal integral model of elasticity. According to this modern strategy, the nonlocal elastic strain is expressed as a convolution integral of the stress field with a suitable smoothing kernel. The plan is the following. Basic assumptions and incremental equilibrium equations governing a straight Bernoulli-Euler nano-beam pre-stressed by an axial force are collected in Section 2. A short description of the stress-driven nonlocal integral model is provided in Section 3. It is also pointed out that the stress-driven integral law, formulated by the special bi-exponential kernel proposed by Helmholtz, is equivalent to a differential nonlocal problem, equipped with homogeneous constitutive boundary conditions, which leads to well-posed elastostatic problems. The incremental nonlocal elastic equilibrium equations to be managed to detect buckling loads of straight nano-beams pre-stressed by an axial force are formulated in Section 4. Numerical evaluations and comparisons of the results with pertinent ones of strain gradient elasticity theory are carried out in Section 5 for selected simple case-studies of technical interest.
CONTACT R. Luciano luciano@unicas.it Department of Civil and Mechanical Engineering, University of Cassino and Southern Lazio, Cassino FR, via G. Di Biasio 43, Cassino 03043, Italy. Color versions of one or more of the figures in the article can be found online at www.tandfonline.com/umcm. 2019 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC

sections.heading: 2. Bernoulli-Euler beams: kinematics and incremental equilibrium
sections.text:
Let us consider a straight nano-beam of length l, whose axis x originates at the left structural end. Each point of the beam axis is thus detected by the coordinate x 2 ½0; l : “Small” motions in the plane labeled by the Cartesian coordinates x, y for a purely flexible (a.k.a. Bernoulli-Euler) beam are described by the transverse displacement field v : ½0; l 7!R along the bending direction y. In this context, small cross-sectional rotation hðxÞ and linearized bending curvature vðxÞ of the beam axis are expressed by [37]
h xð Þ ¼ dv dx ; v xð Þ ¼ dh dx ¼ d 2v dx2 : (1)
Equation (1) states that cross-sections rotate by the same amount of the slope of the deflected axis of the beam, remaining orthogonal to it. It has to be remarked that the quantities in Eq. (1) are actually first-order increments of the corresponding kinematical quantities with respect to an evolution parameter, starting from the straight (undeformed) beam. This is important when dealing with buckling phenomena, since one investigates first-order load-stress increments with respect to an existing load-stress state, see e.g., [38–40].
Once defined kinematics, the mechanical actions are duals of the test fields with respect to the external and internal power, and the balance of force and torque naturally derives from the equilibrium condition of virtual power. For a plane beam, the mechanical actions are a force (at a distance and by contact) with two components and a couple (at a distance and by contact) with just one component. In static problems, like the one considered here, it is usual to neglect actions at a distance; the actions by contact turn out to be equal to inner actions, and are usually decomposed into force components normal and parallel to the cross-section (normal and shearing forces NðxÞ;TðxÞ , respectively) and a single couple component orthogonal to the plane of motion (bending moment interaction M(x)). By the balance of virtual power, the balance of force and torque is obtained in the form of three scalar first-order differential equations in terms of fields NðxÞ;TðxÞ;MðxÞ.
Performing a formal power series expansion in terms of an evolution perturbation parameter up to the first order, in order to consider “small” perturbations of the reference shape, and considering an axial load P soliciting the reference shape in traction, one has
N0 xð Þ ¼ P; T0 xð Þ M0 xð Þ ¼ 0; (2) as far as the pre-stress state is concerned, whence the subscript 0; in addition, it is
dN xð Þ dx ¼ 0; dT xð Þ dx þ v xð ÞN0 xð Þ ¼ 0; dM xð Þdx þ T xð Þ ¼ 0 (3)
for the incremental stress state, where the fields without superscripts are now first-order increments, in order to simplify the notation. The incremental balance for the axial force is decoupled from the balance of transverse actions
(shearing force and bending couple), thus, we will focus on the latter. By replacing Eqs. (1) and (2) into Eq. (3), and limiting to the transverse behavior, yields
d2M xð Þ dx2 d 2v xð Þ dx2 P ¼ 0 ) M xð Þ ¼ Pv xð Þ þ a1xþ a2 (4)
The differential equation (4) provides the bending moment interaction in terms of the tensile pre-stress and of two constants a1, a2; the actual solution corresponding to each actual case depends on the boundary conditions on M(x). These cannot be provided unless the considered nanobeam is statically determined; in general, to close the problem one shall provide the dependence of the first-order bending moment interaction on the transverse incremental displacement, i.e., the constitutive relation between stress and strain.
It is known that in structural problems involving microand nano-scales, the classical local linearly elastic law is not able to describe size-effects. The hypothesis of simple local material behaviours, is therefore relaxed by adopting suitable size-dependent constitutive models. Thus, one could consider either a stress-driven nonlocal response (the elastic strain depends on the stress of points “far” from the considered one) or a higher strain gradient response (the stress depends on the elastic strain and on its gradients). Both choices are considered in the literature, as discussed in the introductory section.
Recently, in [10] and [33] it was proven that Eringen’s strain-driven integral constitutive equation [5,6], in which the stress depends on the elastic strain of points “far” from the considered one, cannot be adopted to assess size-effects in nano-structures defined in bounded domains. This conclusion is motivated from the fact that suitable constitutive boundary conditions associated with the strain-driven nonlocal law are in contrast with equilibrium requirements. Accordingly, the corresponding nonlocal elastostatic problem of a nano-beam admits no solution for all structural schemes of technical interest. An effective remedy to this difficulty consists in adopting the stress-driven nonlocal integral elastic model, recently proposed in [26] and summarized in the present paper in Section 3.

sections.heading: 3. Stress-driven integral elastic model
sections.text:
In integral elasticity, the stress-driven nonlocal model for inflected slender nano-beams is defined by the convolution
vel xð Þ ¼ ðL 0 /k x nð Þ C M nð Þ dn; (5)
with vel elastic curvature, C local elastic compliance and /k kernel function depending on a dimensionless nonlocal parameter k>0 . Let E is the Euler-Young modulus. The compliance C is the inverse of the local elastic stiffness
K :¼ ð X E y2dA: (6)
The kernel function fulfills parity, positivity and limit impulsivity
/k xð Þ ¼ /k xð Þ 0; lim k!0þ /k xð Þ ¼ d xð Þ; (
(7)
where d is the Dirac unit impulse at 0 2 R and the limit being intended in distributional terms
lim k!0þ ðþ1 1 /k x nð Þ f nð Þ dn ¼ f xð Þ; 8 f 2 C0 R;Rð Þ: (8)
Hereafter, we will assume the following special bi-exponential form of the kernel
/k xð Þ :¼ 1 2 lc exp jxj lc ; (9)
where the length characteristic lc , expressing the amplitude of the range of nonlocal action, is defined by lc :¼ kl. As proven in [26], the output of the stress-driven integral convolution Eq. (5), described by the special kernel Eq. (9), provides the unique solution of the constitutive differential equation
vel xð Þ l2c d 2vel dx2 xð Þ ¼ C M l2c xð Þ; (10)
with the constitutive boundary conditions
dvel dx 0ð Þ ¼ 1 lc vel 0ð Þ;
dvel dx lð Þ ¼ 1 lc vel lð Þ:
8>< >: (11)
Geometric and elastic bending curvature fields are assumed to be coincident in the sequel v ¼ vel , since a purely elastic constitutive behavior is investigated.

sections.heading: 4. Buckling
sections.text:
The incremental nonlocal elastic problem of an initially axially stressed nano-beam associated with the stress-driven elastic model illustrated in Section 3 can be formulated by adopting the integral relation Eq. (5) or the equivalent set of differential and boundary conditions Eqs. (10) and (11).
To this end, replacing Eq. (1) and (4) into Eqs. (10) and (11), we get the basic equations governing the relevant incremental elastic problem
d2v xð Þ dx2 l2c d4v xð Þ dx4 ¼ Pv xð Þ þ a1xþ a2 C ;
d3v xð Þ dx3

These equations will be equipped with kinematic boundary conditions (free ends, hinges, simple supports, clamps).
In order to abstract from particular values of the physical quantities involved, the following non-dimensional parameters are introduced

where Pe is the known Eulerian buckling load for a pinnedpinned local elastic beam. Inserting Eq. (13) into Eq. (12) we get the non-dimensional counterpart of the latter
k2g0000 nð Þ g00 nð Þ þ ap2g nð Þ þ b1nþ b2 ¼ 0; g000 0ð Þ ¼ g 00 0ð Þ k ; g000 1ð Þ ¼ g 00 1ð Þ k

sections.heading: 5. Case studies
sections.text:
Buckling loads for some benchmark cases, as a function of the non-dimensional nonlocal parameter k, are evaluated. Since the governing equations, equipped with the constitutive boundary conditions in a non-dimensional form are defined in Eq. (14), only kinematic and static boundary conditions have to be prescribed to achieve this goal. Numerical results will be compared with those provided by the strain gradient elasticity theory and collected in tables and figures. A close look at a model encompassing both nonlocal and gradient elasticity theories [41–43] makes it easy to see that the difference with the governing problem in Eq. (14) is represented by the constitutive boundary conditions, which for the strain gradient elasticity theory are
C d3v xð Þ dx3
x¼0;l
¼ 0 ) g000j jn¼0;1 ¼ 0 (15)
in dimensional and non-dimensional form, respectively.

sections.heading: 5.1. Pinned-pinned beam
sections.text:
The governing problem Eq. (14) in this case is supplemented by the boundary conditions
v 0ð Þ ¼ 0; v lð Þ ¼ 0; M 0ð Þ ¼ 0; M lð Þ ¼ 0: (16) It follows that a1 ¼ a2 ¼ 0 in Eq. (12)1, hence b1 ¼ b2 ¼ 0 in Eq. (14). Thus, the only remaining boundary conditions to be fulfilled are the first two in Eq. (16), which have the non-dimensional form
g 0ð Þ ¼ 0; g 1ð Þ ¼ 0 (17) Introducing these boundary conditions in Eq. (14) we get an algebraic homogeneous problem in the integration constants, which admits a non-trivial solution, implying a nonstraight buckled configuration adjacent to the reference one, if and only if the determinant of the associated matrix of coefficients vanishes. The results are depicted in Figure 1, where the intersection of the red surface (the real part of the above quoted determinant) with the blue plane (representing zero level) is the curve of the buckling load versus the non-locality parameter, which is assumed to vary between 0.001 and 0.5.
Buckling is possible only for negative values of the applied axial load, i.e., for compressive pre-stress; this is a well-known result of structural mechanics, which founds confirmation here. It is worth noting that when the nonlocal parameter tends to zero, the non-locality effect tends to vanish, and the non-dimensional buckling load tends to unity, i.e., the buckling load coincides with the expected Euler one. In addition, when the non-locality parameter grows, the nano-beam exhibits a stiffening behavior, viz. the buckling load increases.
This trend is in line with thereoretical predictions corresponding to the adopted stress-driven nonlocal model.
If we evaluate the values of the buckling load and compare them with those obtained by gradient elasticity (GE), we may compile Table 1, where NLE stands for (stressdriven) nonlocal elasticity presented in [26] and [33].
It is worth noting that, as long as the nonlocal effect is reduced to a minimum or almost vanishing, thus tending to describe usual local elasticity, both nonstandard elastic theories provide the same result, i.e., buckling occurs under Euler’s critical load in compression. On the other hand, as soon as k assumes non-negligible values (starting from a material characteristic length which is one-tenth of the beam length stiffening structural responses are highlighted. The difference between pertinent results associated with strain gradient and stressdriven nonlocal models becomes meaningful for significant values of the nonlocal parameter for increasing values of the nonlocal parameter. For k¼ 1 (i.e. the material characteristic length equals the beam length, that implies that all points of the beam axis significantly affect the behavior of all the other points) this difference is about 61%, gradient elasticity foreseeing a critical load slightly greater than the Euler one, while nonlocal elasticity yields a critical load three times larger than the Euler one.

sections.heading: 5.2. Clamped-free beam
sections.text:
The governing problem in Eq. (14) in this case is supplemented by the boundary conditions
v 0ð Þ ¼ 0; h 0ð Þ ¼ 0; M lð Þ ¼ 0; T lð Þ þ Ph lð Þ ¼ 0 (18) The first two in Eq. (18) express the constraint conditions at the origin, while the last two in Eq. (18) express the vanishing of the bending moment increment. No couple is applied and the shearing force is the projection of the axial pre-stress along the cross section. Equation (18) have nondimensional form (see Eqs. 12 and 13)
g 0ð Þ ¼ 0; g0 0ð Þ ¼ 0; k2g0000 1ð Þ þ g00 1ð Þ ¼ 0; k2g00000 1ð Þ g000 1ð Þ þ ap2g0 1ð Þ ¼ 0 (19)
Introducing Eq. (19) into Eq. (14), we get an algebraic homogeneous problem in the integration constants, which admits non-trivial solution, i.e., a non-straight buckled
configuration adjacent to the reference one, if and only if the determinant of the associated matrix of coefficients vanishes. The results are depicted in Figure 2, where the intersection of the red surface (the real part of the above quoted determinant) with the blue plane (representing zero level) is the curve of the buckling load versus the non-locality parameter, which is assumed to vary between 0.001 and 0.5.
Buckling is again possible only for compressive pre-stress, as well-known in structural mechanics. Again, when the nonlocal parameter tends to zero, the non-locality effect tends to vanish, and the non-dimensional buckling load tends to 1/4, i.e., the buckling load equals the Euler’s one, as expected. When the non-locality parameter grows, the nanobeam again exhibits a stiffening behavior, since the buckling load parameter increases; similar comments as those brought for the pinned-pinned beam may be repeated. Numerical evidences are collected in Table 2 and compared with pertinent results of the strain gradient elasticity theory.

sections.heading: 5.3. Clamped-pinned beam
sections.text:
The governing problem in Eq. (14) in this case is supplemented by the boundary conditions
v 0ð Þ ¼ 0; h 0ð Þ ¼ 0; v lð Þ ¼ 0; M lð Þ ¼ 0 (20) The first two in Eq. (20) express the constraint conditions at the origin, while the last two in Eq. (20) express the constraint condition at the other end, plus the vanishing of the bending moment increment. Equation (20) has non-dimensional form (see Eqs. 12 and 13)
g 0ð Þ ¼ 0; g0 0ð Þ ¼ 0; g 1ð Þ ¼ 0; k2g0000 1ð Þ þ g00 1ð Þ ¼ 0 (21)
Introducing Eq. (21) into Eq. (14), we get an algebraic homogeneous problem in the integration constants, which

admits non-trivial solution, i.e., a non-straight buckled configuration adjacent to the reference one, if and only if the determinant of the associated matrix of coefficients vanishes. The results are depicted in Figure 3, where the intersection of the red surface (the real part of the above quoted determinant) with the blue plane (representing zero level) is the curve of the buckling load versus the non-locality parameter, assumed to vary between 0.001 and 0.5.
Buckling occurs only for compressive pre-stress, as usual; when the nonlocal parameter tends to zero, the non-locality effect tends to vanish, and the non-dimensional buckling load tends to 2 , i.e., the buckling load equals the Euler’s one, as expected. When the non-locality parameter grows, the nano-beam again exhibits a stiffening behavior, since the buckling load parameter increases; similar comments as above may be repeated. Numerical results are reported in Table 3 and compared with those obtained by the strain gradient elasticity theory.

sections.heading: 5.4. Clamped-clamped beam
sections.text:
The governing problem in Eq. (14) in this case is supplemented by the boundary conditions
v 0ð Þ ¼ 0; v lð Þ ¼ 0; h 0ð Þ ¼ 0; h lð Þ ¼ 0 (22) expressing the constraint condition at the ends of the beam, and have the non-dimensional form
g 0ð Þ ¼ 0; g 1ð Þ ¼ 0; g0 0ð Þ ¼ 0; g0 1ð Þ ¼ 0 (23) Introducing these boundary conditions in Eq. (14), we get an algebraic homogeneous problem in the integration constants, which admits non-trivial buckled solutions if and only if the determinant of the associated matrix of coefficients vanishes. The results are depicted in Figure 4, where the intersection of the red surface (the real part of the above quoted determinant) with the blue plane (representing zero level) is the curve of the buckling load versus the non-locality parameter, which is assumed to vary between 0.001 and 0.5.
Buckling occurs only for compressive pre-stress, as usual, and when the non-locality effect tends to vanish, the nondimensional buckling load tends to 4 and the physical buckling load equals Euler’s, as expected. The nano-beam exhibits a stiffening behavior with increasing non-locality, and the buckling load parameter grows very fast, in accordance with both the stiffer structural scheme and the stiffening effect of nonlocal elasticity.
If we evaluate the values of the buckling load and compare them with those obtained by gradient elasticity, we may compile Table 4. As already seen, as long as the nonlocal effect is reduced to a minimum or almost vanishing, thus tending to describe usual local elasticity, both nonstandard elastic theories provide the same result, i.e., buckling
occurs under Euler’s critical load in compression. As soon as the material characteristic length becomes one-tenth of the actual beam length, it is true that gradient elasticity also describes a stiffening behavior, but provides results lower than those obtained by the stress-driven integral nonlocal law.

sections.heading: 6. Closing remarks
sections.text:
The stress-driven pure nonlocal integral elasticity model, recently proposed in [26] for a mathematically and mechanically consistent analysis of size-effects in nanostructures, has been adopted in this paper to investigate the buckling of straight nano-beams pre-stressed by an axial force.
It has been found that in all cases buckling may occur only for negative values of the applied force, i.e., for initial compressive loads, as it is well known in mechanics of
Figure 3. Buckling loads of a clamped-pinned stress-driven nonlocal elastic nano-beam.
Table 3. Buckling loads of a clamped-pinned nano-beam for nonlocal and gradient elasticity.
k 0.0001 .001 0.01 0.1 0.5
NLE –2.04595 –2.04784 –2.07058 –2.65883 –4.74732 GE –2.04575 –2.04579 –2.05020 –2.40672 –3.71747 D, % –0.01 –0.10 –0.98 –9.48 –16.03
Figure 4. Buckling loads of a clamped-clamped stress-driven nonlocal elastic nano-beam.
structures; in addition, when non-locality tends to zero, and the material tends to respond according to a simple, local elastic law, the usual Euler’s critical loads for the corresponding schemes are found again. On the other hand, when the material length characterizing non-locality grows, starting from approximately one-tenth of the physical length of the nano-beam the structural element begins to exhibit a remarkable stiffening behavior, which is exalted when the ends of the beam are subjected to progressively stiffer constraints. Unlike Eringen’s strain-driven integral elasticity model, which is inapplicable to structural problems of technical interest [10] and [12], no paradoxical effects are encountered in the present analysis. Merits and structural implications of the stress-driven model with respect to the classical strain-driven formulation is carried out in [33] by investigating the size-dependent behavior of inflected nanobeams. Effectiveness of the proposed nonlocal methodology is tested by examining selected structural schemes of technical interest undergoing buckling. The corresponding buckling loads, compared with those obtained by strain gradient elasticity theory, provide an effective guide for the analysis and design of modern devices for nanotechnological applications.

referenceMentions.context: The differential law, consequent (but not equivalent) to the strain-driven nonlocal integral law proposed by Eringen in his seminal contributions [5] and [6], is the most used model to study nanostructures, see the review papers [7–9] and the references cited therein.

The differential law, consequent (but not equivalent) to the strain-driven nonlocal integral law proposed by Eringen in his seminal contributions [5] and [6], is the most used model to study nanostructures, see the review papers [7–9] and the references cited therein.

In a recent paper [10], it has been shown that, adopting the special bi-exponential kernel, the differential law of Eringen is equivalent to the integral one provided that suitable homogeneous constitutive boundary conditions (CBC) are verified.
On the contrary, in structural problems of engineering interest CBC are in contrast with equilibrium requirements and therefore the consequent elastostatic problems are ill-posed [11].
However, in literature, CBC are often improperly disregarded [12].

All these difficulties can be overcome by adopting the innovative nonlocal constitutive theory, of stress-driven type, proposed in [26] and applied in [27–32] to investigate size-dependent static and dynamic responses of nano-beams.
In this context, small cross-sectional rotation hðxÞ and linearized bending curvature vðxÞ of the beam axis are expressed by [37]

Recently, in [10] and [33] it was proven that Eringen’s strain-driven integral constitutive equation [5,6], in which the stress depends on the elastic strain of points “far” from the considered one, cannot be adopted to assess size-effects in nano-structures defined in bounded domains.

Recently, in [10] and [33] it was proven that Eringen’s strain-driven integral constitutive equation [5,6], in which the stress depends on the elastic strain of points “far” from the considered one, cannot be adopted to assess size-effects in nano-structures defined in bounded domains.
An effective remedy to this difficulty consists in adopting the stress-driven nonlocal integral elastic model, recently proposed in [26] and summarized in the present paper in Section 3.

Unlike Eringen’s strain-driven integral elasticity model, which is inapplicable to structural problems of technical interest [10] and [12], no paradoxical effects are encountered in the present analysis.

Unlike Eringen’s strain-driven integral elasticity model, which is inapplicable to structural problems of technical interest [10] and [12], no paradoxical effects are encountered in the present analysis.

Merits and structural implications of the stress-driven model with respect to the classical strain-driven formulation is carried out in [33] by investigating the size-dependent behavior of inflected nanobeams.

metadata.abstractText: Size-dependent buckling of compressed Bernoulli-Euler nano-beams is investigated by stressdriven nonlocal continuum mechanics. The nonlocal elastic strain is obtained by convoluting the stress field with a suitable smoothing kernel. Incremental equilibrium equations are established by a standard perturbation technique. Higher-order constitutive boundary conditions are naturally inferred by the stress-driven nonlocal integral convolution, equipped with the special bi-exponential kernel. Buckling loads of compressed nano-beams, with kinematic boundary constraints of applicative interest, are numerically calculated and compared with those obtained by the theory of strain gradient elasticity. ARTICLE HISTORY Received 12 July 2018 Accepted 12 July 2018
